This game is amazing.

It's like if fast and furious, dead rising, and you're favorite mafia movie all fused together. 

The main story is phenomenal, but where the real fun is the bonus/side content which from my understanding are these games specialty. So many fun side mini games to get lost in and the game actually rewards you for doing their side content with the completion points which essentially upgrade your character. Some of the mini games can be a bit of a hassle or have a learning curve(Mahjong), but for the most part they break up the game play in a fun way that kept my brain satisfied.

The performances by the entire cast here is truly something to behold, it takes a very good performance to get you out of the goofy mindset of firing you're fish cannon, and this cast pulls it off in spades. Particularly Kiryu and Majima. These have to be some of the best protagonists I've ever encountered. The emotion they get out of Kiryu and Majimas face models is very impressive.

The environment design is also incredibly impressive. The amount of detail in Kamurocho makes it all feel real in a way to where I play with the sub cause it's as if I'm walking around japan. A lot of games can feel a tad empty in their city design where it'll feel like a ghost town, not here. This is a cut above most rpgs, which is unexpected because  this game is nearly a decade old. 

The story is structured masterfully, just the right amount of twists and turns, I was actively curious where it was all heading to towards the end. The handful of antagonists in this game are some of my favorites across any medium. The facial design and background of these villain esque chracters are very well crafted. 

I'm sold on the series and will be venturing to Kiwami next. :)

Review: Yakuza 0 ‚Äî (9/10)

Yakuza 0 is one of those rare games that completely immerses you in a time and place. Its recreation of 1980s Japan during the economic boom is nothing short of spectacular‚Äîneon-drenched streets, exuberant nightlife, and an atmosphere that effortlessly captures the era‚Äôs swagger. Combine that with a strong, emotionally charged story featuring Kiryu and Majima at their most raw and human, and you get an experience that stays with you long after the credits roll.

The game‚Äôs breadth of activities is almost overwhelming in the best way: cabaret club management, real estate battles, disco dancing, pocket circuit racing, karaoke, darts, pool, bowling, and countless street distractions that make Kamurocho and Sotenbori feel alive. I loved how 80s nostalgia serves the story well, and the mostly fun substories add a layer of grounded absurdity the series is known for.

That said, Yakuza 0 isn‚Äôt flawless. The combat can feel repetitive after a while, even with the multiple fighting styles. Some QoL improvements‚Äîlike faster menu flow, less backtracking, or more intuitive upgrade gating‚Äîwould have gone a long way. Substories, while entertaining, often lack real narrative depth and feel more like quick comedic sketches than engaging side plots. And the CP system isn‚Äôt particularly compelling; it exists more as a checklist than something that meaningfully enhances the experience.

Still, these issues don‚Äôt detract from what Yakuza 0 ultimately is: a stylish, heartfelt, and often hilarious crime drama wrapped in the best representation of 80s Japan you can find in gaming. Its emotional highs, memorable characters, and richly textured world make it an absolute must-play.

Final Verdict: 9/10

This game blew me away with the quality of its storytelling and the depth of its characters. As a new entrant to the series I'd heard a lot of great things and finally taking the plunge did not disappoint. If you're a fan of games with visceral brawler combat, a deep and emotionally charged narrative, and an excellent balance of surrealist humour and grounded social commentary, I'd heartily recommend picking this up.

The combat feels visceral and well paced, the Heat move finishers are dramatic and animated beautifully. The camera can sometimes be difficult to control and the automatic lock-on system doesn't always feel as precise as you'd want it to. The boss fights are visually spectacular, intercut with over the top brawling, though on higher difficulties the health bars can be daunting and make the fights last a little too long. My main complaint is the enemies propensity for stun-locking combos that have to be anticipated rather than avoided by reflex, which breaks the flow of aggression.

At first I was sceptical about the games' rapidly shifting tone, from serious drama to anime goofiness on a dime, but it really becomes part of the charm. Having a scene that wouldn't be out of place in a Japanese version of The Godfather cut right into a 20-man brawl where you beat enemies over the head with a bicycle just becomes part of the flow, and its pure fun every time.

The representation of 1980s Japan, its urban sprawl, economic boom and rampant consumerism are on full display, and the wide array of in-depth minigames, restaurants and locals you can interact with really sell the diversity of experience and face-paced rat race associated with city life. And acts in perfect contrast to the seedy underbelly lurking behind the facade of neon.
